Award.AwardTitle: MRI: Development of Three Wave Mixing Spectrometer for Chiral Analysis by Rotational Spectroscopy
Award.AbstractNarration:
With this award from the Major Research Instrumentation (MRI) Program and the Chemistry Research Instrumentation (CRIF) Program, Professors Brooks Pate and colleague Kevin Lehmann from the University of Virginia will develop a new instrument that involves Fourier transform microwave spectrometry for the study of chiral molecules. Molecular chirality is the property of molecules to exhibit handedness by existing in two forms (called enantiomers) which are mirror images, like left and right hands in humans. A molecule's left form (enantiomer) may react differently than its right form (enantiomer). Many pharmaceuticals can exist in both forms. However, only one will generally be medically effective. With this award the team will develop an instrument to analyze samples to determine the relative amounts of each enantiomer in a given sample (enantiomeric excess). The instrument will use a recently developed procedure using a microwave spectrometer involving analysis of three gas phase rotational transitions which are coupled through common energy levels (three wave mixing). This technique could have important practical applications in the analysis of reaction mixtures employed in drug preparations or materials research.

The instrument would allow chiral analysis using three wave mixing Fourier transform rotational spectroscopy. The instrument uses design principles that have been developed for broadband, chirped-pulse Fourier transform rotational spectroscopy and it will be capable of making three essential chiral analysis measurements: (a) quantitative measurement of the yields of diastereomers produced in the synthesis of a molecule with multiple chiral centers; (b) quantitative measurement of the enantiomeric excess of each diastereomer in a sample; and (c) accurate determination of the absolute configuration (or handedness) of the enantiomer that is in excess.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit

The NSF Major Research Instrumentation project focused on developing a recent discovery in the field of molecular spectroscopy, called three-wave mixing rotational spectroscopy, into a useful technique in chemical analysis.  Three-wave mixing rotational spectroscopy provides a way to analyze the mirror image structure of molecules – a property called chirality.  When chiral molecules interact, they can have different outcomes depending this handedness.  In the field of pharmaceutical chemistry, knowledge of the chiral purity is crucial in developing safe and effective drugs.  The discovery of three-wave mixing rotational spectroscopy held the promise of a rapid, high-confidence method to perform chiral analysis in analytical chemistry.  This project developed both the theoretical foundations of the technique and introduced an instrument design capable of making quantitative measurements of the enantiomeric excess – a measure of the relative composition of left- and right-handed versions of the molecule.

During the course of the project, the analytical chemistry needs of the pharmaceutical chemistry industry were explored through a series of collaborations.  These discussions identified shortcomings of the three-wave mixing technique.  One of the greatest limitations is that three-wave mixing rotational spectroscopy requires a sample of known chiral purity for calibration.  Much of the need for chiral analysis in industry and academic research is for the “first time” analysis of a newly synthesized molecule.  In response, to the unmet needs in industry, a second chiral analysis methodology using rotational spectroscopy, called chiral tag rotational spectroscopy, was developed and tested.  This approach can be used to analyze a previously unknown molecule.  The chiral tag method was also shown to have higher measurement accuracy that three-wave mixing rotational spectroscopy.  The final instrument created through this project is capable of implementing both three-wave mixing and chiral tag measurement approaches.

Perhaps the most important advantage of rotational spectroscopy approaches to chiral analysis is that the technique can perform the measurement directly on a complex sample mixture.  The existing methods for chiral analysis require prior chemical isolation of the analyte of interest using chromatography.  The development of separation methodologies for chiral molecules is expensive and time consuming.  Rotational spectroscopy instruments offer unmatched spectral resolution and this confers the advantage that the spectrum of a sample with multiple chemical components will still provide clear differentiation of the mixture components.  One of the key demonstrations of measurement capabilities performed in this work is the analysis of the enantiomer distribution of multiple molecules present in essential oils.

 

Broader Impacts

Translation of the results into new products has been a focus of the project.  A patent application has been filed for the new methodology of chiral tag rotational spectroscopy and this patent is licensed to BrightSpec.  The technique has been tested for several analyses identified by the chemical and pharmaceutical industry.  BrightSpec is currently building lab services capabilities to meet the needs of industry.

 The ability of rotational spectroscopy-based techniques to perform chemical analysis in complex chemical mixtures is crucial to developing new chemical production methods based on flow chemistry.  Flow chemistry has the potential to significantly lower the cost of chemical production and reduce the capital investment required for new production facilities.  However, because these methods work on the principle of continuous production, they require real-time analysis methods that can use samples directly form the reaction mixture.  The techniques developed in this project have been evaluated for use in flow chemistry pharmaceutical production through a collaboration with the Medicines for All program at Virginia Commonwealth University.  The goal of this program is to lower the production costs of essential medicines so that they can be distributed more broadly in developing nations.

The instrument built from this project is now operating full time and hosting collaborative projects from academic, government, and industry groups.  The instrument is also used for undergraduate instruction in the design of instruments and applications of chiral analysis to pharmaceutical chemistry.
